utterances: At the United Nations, the man in charge of emergency relief operations, John Holmes, says this is one area that he's now working on, trying to mount a vaccination campaign and fill the many gaps left by the expelled aid groups.
Holmes is also trying to get a better sense of what President Bashir means by his latest threat — to get rid of all foreign aid groups and Sudanize relief work in the country.
Obviously the idea that we would simply hand over goods at the port to be distributed or monitored without our involvement is not one that would not be acceptable to us.
We need to make sure that our aid is distributed and monitored according to our standards, so it doesn't look very realistic to us as presently expressed.

Activists who held a teleconference about Darfur yesterday say President Bashir seems to be in the mood to escalate his standoff with the West, and they see this is a test not only for the United Nations but for the Obama administration.
John Norris of the Enough Project called on President Obama to lead a concerted diplomatic effort to make it clear to Khartoum that its behavior is unacceptable.
Jerry Fowler, who runs the Save Darfur Coalition, is also waiting to see the White House act.

Why is there a disconnect between how passionately and articulately candidate Obama addressed the issue of Darfur and said that the genocide there is a stain on our souls — and what President Obama is doing and saying now with millions of lives at stake?
We need presidential engagement and we need it now.
State Department spokesman Robert Wood said he expects the administration will name a special envoy for Sudan, but no decision has been made.
Fowler says the situation on the ground won't wait for U.S.
policy reviews.

If the administration is not ready to appoint the envoy, then there needs to be a temporary owner; someone who is already on board needs to drop what he or she is doing and focus on this crisis, because it's not going to wait.

As for the aid groups, Joel Charny of Refugees International says they should be allowed back to Darfur because of the humanitarian needs and should not be part of any deal-making on the International Criminal Court case against President Bashir.
Michele Kelemen, NPR News, Washington.
Being blacklisted in Hollywood means a whole different thing these days.
Being on it can be one of the best things for a budding young screenwriter.
The Black List was started a few years ago.
It features the best unproduced screenplays of the year.
A film executive named Franklin Leonard puts it together.
Three years ago, screenplays for the films ""Juno"" and ""500 Days of Summer"" were discovered on his list.
And Leonard puts it together, he says, because so many good scripts get lost in the pile of the thousands that are written.
And in Leonard's case, he can only read a fraction of them.
A fair estimate is somewhere between 10 to 15 a week.
So you're probably reading between 500 to 1,000 screenplays in a given year.
And maybe none of those will be optioned, right?
That's entirely possible, yes.
Let's talk about some of the films that made the list this year, and I want to start by asking about this one.
This is my personal favorite.
Do we need to bleep this out?
We'll call it ""Romancing Jane Austen."" It's really the F-word there, instead of the R-word that I just used.
This seems like a Bill & Ted's-style adventure of two guys who go back in time, and they have to convince Jane Austen to have relations with one of them.
Can you tell me the story?

It's the story of several young men, frustrated by the unreasonable expectations that Jane Austen's novels have created in modern romance, find themselves back in time, and the only way to return to their modern day is by seducing Jane Austen.
And that - has that been optioned?
Is that going to be made?
To my knowledge, it remains a currently available script.
But I believe it has producers attached.
Take note.
Take note.
Let me ask you about another one that made the Black List.
This is called ""College Republicans.
Yes, this year's number one script.

And for a debate on this endorsement and more, we have Robert George, associate editorial page editor for the New York Post; and Donna Brazile, a nationally syndicated columnist who also teaches at Georgetown University.
And I'm here in the same room with Donna.
I love these East Coast swings.
Thanks guys.
It's a great honor to be in a room with you, too.
Thank you.
It's so wonderful…
How are you doing, Robert?
It is so wonderful to be on the air with two of my favorite African-American women in the media.
So…
Oh, boy.
God bless you, Robert.
We start now with all sorts of pats on the back.
So I'm going go to you first, Robert.
Barack Obama - definitely someone with a broad constituency.
What do you make of Congressman Jackson's point that, in a way, he has to reach the black community now that he started with a Rainbow Coalition and now has to reach into the black community?
Yeah, indeed, I mean, it's somewhat ironic because people would say, well, you know, he's African-American; he's actually literally African-American since his father is African, but it's true.

And I think frankly, though, it shows the maturity of the African-American constituency in the context - well, particularly within, we'll say, in the Democratic Party that the African-American candidate has to ask for their vote and work for their vote just as well as the white candidate - the leading white candidate - in this case being Hillary Rodham Clinton.
The community is looking and saying, you know, there are reasons why I could vote for Hillary Clinton, there are reasons why I could vote for Barack Obama.
So Obama has to work and ask for that vote as well.
He can't take it for granted.
And, Donna, he can't take it for granted from the Congressional Black Caucus.
They're split down the middle - 12 members of the CBC endorsed Clinton; 12 - excluding Obama - endorsed Obama.
What about that split as well?
I think Senator Obama is having a difficult time reaching African-American leaders although he just received the endorsement of our - the nation's only black governor, Deval Patrick.
The problem is, is history.
Senator Clinton has a story working with members of Congressional Black Caucus as first lady, of course, and now as the junior senator from New York.
Obama has an opportunity to reach a large segment of the black community.
The national polls right now are a reflection of a broader name identification and historic connections.
But Senator Obama can really win the South Carolina primary.
Representative Jackson is right.
The black vote will represent about 50 percent of the total voting age population.
Black women will play an even larger role.
They make a one-third of the electorate.
In South Carolina: Again, Obama has an opportunity to win in South Carolina.
He will do very well in the first two contests.
And then on February 5th, which is essentially a national primary day, over 30 percent of the delegates chosen that day will be African-Americans.
So, once again, Obama has a real shot at winning the Democratic nomination despite what the national polls are saying.

What's so interesting here, though, is that the whole question of a so-called identity politics is really being kind of turned - has been turned on its head because, you know, on the one hand, people are looking at this as Barack Obama, a black man seeking black votes and so forth.

But, you know, if you've taken into the factor, as Donna said, the issue of black women, you know, are they supposed to be thinking off - in terms of being black and going for the black man or are they supposed to be taking in terms of being women and going for the woman?
And, in fact, women in either party are more likely to vote.
And so that is, in a sense, where the issue could really hang.
I want to turn us to another topic.
California is burning, and the president plans a trip that will bring him to southern California tomorrow.
These wildfires have forced some survivors in and out of San Diego's Qualcomm Stadium.
The president was on vacation when the levees broke in New Orleans.
And he flew over five days later after the state of emergency.
Super Dome victims there are not always having water sanitation.
In terms of the federal response, Donna, how do you compare?
I think the White House responded almost immediately to the request by the government to send in supplies.
FEMA was on the spot in Sacramento almost instantaneously.
Both Chertoff, the secretary of Homeland Security, as well as Mr. Paulson arrived in California yesterday without all of the paperwork.
I think they learned from their mistakes.

Look, back in 2005, we thought FEMA stood for federal employees missing in action because they were missing for so many days in helping the people, the flood victims of Louisiana, as people stood out waiting for water.

But yesterday, the White House released, not just HUD to send in supplies, but other federal agencies - the Department of Interior, Department of Agriculture - making sure that people who were in the stadium have blankets.
They have food.
And I think they've learned the lesson.
And we should also give credit to the first responders in San Diego.
They have put together a local emergency call system that allowed them to alert 400,000 residents within hours of the emergency.
So they were able to evacuate in a timely manner.
So there are lessons to be learned from this process.
And also…
Deer-o-vision

I think that the only way that we're going to evacuate at this point is if the smoke conditions get to an extreme or if it becomes a fire hazard because we are not - we're a little ways down from the path.
We may potentially be in the clear.
The problem is it hasn't hit a house yet - and structures, and so we don't know if the fire conditions are going to be extreme.
We don't know if the smoke conditions are going to be extreme.
I don't know if I want to leave my merchandise here as things are burning - for smoke damage.
So there's a lot of variables that are uncertain at this point.
Are you ready to get out of there?
We have boxes and plastic storage bins ready, and we're having a huge sale trying to thin out our inventory for when we need to pack and go.
How many people live there in Pahoa, Tiffany?
